resource.name: Shareable Measure
resource.description: Enforces the minimum information set for the measure metadata required by HL7 and other organizations that share and publish measures

element.definition: The Measure resource provides the definition of a quality measure.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.

binding.description: IETF language tag

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Canonical identifier for this measure, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this measure when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this measure is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the measure is stored on different servers.
element.requirements: Allows the measure to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this measure when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the measure when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the measure author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence. To provide a version consistent with the Decision Support Service specification, use the format Major.Minor.Revision (e.g. 1.0.0). For more information on versioning knowledge assets, refer to the Decision Support Service specification. Note that a version is required for non-experimental active artifacts.
A natural language name identifying the measure. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the measure.
An explanatory or alternate title for the measure giving additional information about its content.
The status of this measure. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this measure is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level measure.

element.short: E.g. Patient, Practitioner, RelatedPerson, Organization, Location, Device
element.definition: The intended subjects for the measure. If this element is not provided, a Patient subject is assumed, but the subject of the measure can be anything.
element.meaningWhenMissing: Patient

binding.description: The possible types of subjects for a measure (E.g. Patient, Practitioner, Organization, Location, etc.).

element.definition: The population basis specifies the type of elements in the population. For a subject-based measure, this is boolean (because the subject and the population basis are the same, and the population criteria define yes/no values for each individual in the population). For measures that have a population basis that is different than the subject, this element specifies the type of the population basis. For example, an encounter-based measure has a subject of Patient and a population basis of Encounter, and the population criteria all return lists of Encounters.
element.requirements: Allows non-subject-based measures to be specified
element.meaningWhenMissing: boolean

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the measure was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the measure changes.

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the measure.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the measure.  May also allow for contact.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.short: Natural language description of the measure
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the measure from a consumer's perspective.

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate measure instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the measure is intended to be used.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.definition: Explanation of why this measure is needed and why it has been designed as it has.

element.short: Describes the clinical usage of the measure
element.definition: A detailed description, from a clinical perspective, of how the measure is used.
A copyright statement relating to the measure and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the measure.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the measure and/or its content.

element.short: When the measure was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.

element.short: When the measure was last reviewed
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

element.short: When the measure is expected to be used
element.definition: The period during which the measure content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the measure are or are expected to be used instead.

element.short: The category of the measure, such as Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc.
element.definition: Descriptive topics related to the content of the measure. Topics provide a high-level categorization grouping types of measures that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the measure so that it can be found by topical searches.

binding.description: High-level categorization of the definition, used for searching, sorting, and filtering.

element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.
An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.
An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.
An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.
Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, or bibliographic references.
element.requirements: Measures must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

element.definition: A reference to a Library resource containing the formal logic used by the measure.

element.short: Disclaimer for use of the measure or its referenced content
element.definition: Notices and disclaimers regarding the use of the measure or related to intellectual property (such as code systems) referenced by the measure.
element.requirements: Some organizations require that notices and disclosures be included when publishing measures that reference their intellecutal property.

element.definition: Indicates how the calculation is performed for the measure, including proportion, ratio, continuous-variable, and cohort. The value set is extensible, allowing additional measure scoring types to be represented.

binding.description: The scoring type of the measure.

element.definition: Defines the expected units of measure for the measure score. This element SHOULD be specified as a UCUM unit.
element.requirements: When the unit cannot be inferred directly from the calculation logic, this element allows the specification of the desired units of measure of the output.

element.definition: If this is a composite measure, the scoring method used to combine the component measures to determine the composite score.

binding.description: The composite scoring method of the measure.

element.definition: Indicates whether the measure is used to examine a process, an outcome over time, a patient-reported outcome, or a structure measure such as utilization.

binding.description: The type of measure (includes codes from 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.20368).

element.short: How risk adjustment is applied for this measure
element.definition: A description of the risk adjustment factors that may impact the resulting score for the measure and how they may be accounted for when computing and reporting measure results.

element.short: How is rate aggregation performed for this measure
element.definition: Describes how to combine the information calculated, based on logic in each of several populations, into one summarized result.

element.short: Detailed description of why the measure exists
element.definition: Provides a succinct statement of the need for the measure. Usually includes statements pertaining to importance criterion: impact, gap in care, and evidence.
element.requirements: Measure developers need to be able to provide a detailed description of the purpose of the measure. This element provides detailed rationale, where the purpose element provides a summary of the rationale.

element.definition: Provides a summary of relevant clinical guidelines or other clinical recommendations supporting the measure.
Information on whether an increase or decrease in score is the preferred result (e.g., a higher score indicates better quality OR a lower score indicates better quality OR quality is within a range).
element.requirements: Measure consumers and implementers must be able to determine how to interpret a measure score.

binding.description: Observation values that indicate what change in a measurement value or score is indicative of an improvement in the measured item or scored issue.

element.short: Defined terms used in the measure documentation
element.definition: Provides a description of an individual term used within the measure.
element.requirements: Measure developers must be able to provide precise definitions of terms used within measure descriptions and guidance to help communicate the intent of the measure.

element.definition: Additional guidance for the measure including how it can be used in a clinical context, and the intent of the measure.
element.requirements: Measure developers must be able to provide additional guidance for implementers to understand the intent with greater specificity than that provided in the population criteria of the measure. This element provides detailed guidance, where the usage element provides a summary of the guidance.

element.definition: A group of population criteria for the measure.
Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

binding.description: Example of measure groups.

element.definition: The human readable description of this population group.
Indicates whether the measure is used to examine a process, an outcome over time, a patient-reported outcome, or a structure measure such as utilization.

The population basis specifies the type of elements in the population. For a subject-based measure, this is boolean (because the subject and the population basis are the same, and the population criteria define yes/no values for each individual in the population). For measures that have a population basis that is different than the subject, this element specifies the type of the population basis. For example, an encounter-based measure has a subject of Patient and a population basis of Encounter, and the population criteria all return lists of Encounters.

element.short: initial-population | numerator | numerator-exclusion | denominator | denominator-exclusion | denominator-exception | measure-population | measure-population-exclusion | measure-observation
element.definition: The type of population criteria.

binding.description: The type of population.

element.short: The human readable description of this population criteria
element.definition: The human readable description of this population criteria.

element.short: The criteria that defines this population
element.definition: An expression that specifies the criteria for the population, typically the name of an expression in a library.

The id of a population element in this measure that provides the input for this population criteria. In most cases, the scoring structure of the measure implies specific relationships (e.g. the Numerator uses the Denominator as the source in a proportion scoring). In some cases, however, multiple possible choices exist and must be resolved explicitly. For example in a ratio measure with multiple initial populations, the denominator must specify which population should be used as the starting point.
element.requirements: For ratio and continuous variable measures, the source populations must be specified explicitly when they cannot be unambiguously determined from the scoring structure.

element.short: Aggregation method for a measure score (e.g. sum, average, median, minimum, maximum, count)
element.definition: Specifies which method should be used to aggregate measure observation values. For most scoring types, this is implied by scoring (e.g. a proportion measure counts members of the populations). For continuous variables, however, this information must be specified to ensure correct calculation.
element.requirements: For continuous variable measures, specifications must be able to indicate the aggregation method to be used for tallying results from individual observations.

element.definition: The stratifier criteria for the measure report, specified as either the name of a valid CQL expression defined within a referenced library or a valid FHIR Resource Path.

binding.description: Meaning of the stratifier.

element.short: The human readable description of this stratifier
element.definition: The human readable description of this stratifier criteria.

element.short: How the measure should be stratified
element.definition: An expression that specifies the criteria for the stratifier. This is typically the name of an expression defined within a referenced library, but it may also be a path to a stratifier element.

element.short: Stratifier criteria component for the measure
element.definition: A component of the stratifier criteria for the measure report, specified as either the name of a valid CQL expression defined within a referenced library or a valid FHIR Resource Path.

binding.description: Meaning of the stratifier.

element.short: The human readable description of this stratifier component
element.definition: The human readable description of this stratifier criteria component.

element.short: Component of how the measure should be stratified
element.definition: An expression that specifies the criteria for this component of the stratifier. This is typically the name of an expression defined within a referenced library, but it may also be a path to a stratifier element.

element.short: What other data should be reported with the measure
element.definition: The supplemental data criteria for the measure report, specified as either the name of a valid CQL expression within a referenced library, or a valid FHIR Resource Path.

element.definition: Indicates a meaning for the supplemental data. This can be as simple as a unique identifier, or it can establish meaning in a broader context by drawing from a terminology, allowing supplemental data to be correlated across measures.

binding.description: Meaning of the supplemental data.

element.definition: An indicator of the intended usage for the supplemental data element. Supplemental data indicates the data is additional information requested to augment the measure information. Risk adjustment factor indicates the data is additional information used to calculate risk adjustment factors when applying a risk model to the measure calculation.

binding.description: The intended usage for supplemental data elements in the measure.

element.short: The human readable description of this supplemental data
element.definition: The human readable description of this supplemental data.

element.short: Expression describing additional data to be reported
element.definition: The criteria for the supplemental data. This is typically the name of a valid expression defined within a referenced library, but it may also be a path to a specific data element. The criteria defines the data to be returned for this element.

resource.name: Actual Group
resource.description: Enforces an actual group, rather than a definitional group

element.definition: Represents a defined collection of entities that may be discussed or acted upon collectively but which are not expected to act collectively, and are not formally or legally recognized; i.e. a collection of entities that isn't an Organization.

element.definition: A unique business identifier for this group.
element.requirements: Allows the group to be referenced from external specifications.

element.short: Whether this group's record is in active use
element.definition: Indicates whether the record for the group is available for use or is merely being retained for historical purposes.
element.requirements: Need to be able to mark a group record as not to be used because it was created in error or is otherwise no longer available (e.g. a herd that no longer exists).
element.meaningWhenMissing: This resource is generally assumed to be active if no value is provided for the active element

element.short: person | animal | practitioner | device | medication | substance
element.definition: Identifies the broad classification of the kind of resources the group includes.
element.requirements: Identifies what type of resources the group is made up of.

binding.description: Types of resources that are part of group.

element.definition: If true, indicates that the resource refers to a specific group of real individuals.  If false, the group defines a set of intended individuals.
element.requirements: There are use-cases for groups that define specific collections of individuals, and other groups that define "types" of intended individuals.  The requirements for both kinds of groups are similar, so we use a single resource, distinguished by this flag.

element.definition: Provides a specific type of resource the group includes; e.g. "cow", "syringe", etc.

binding.description: Kind of particular resource; e.g. cow, syringe, lake, etc.

element.definition: A label assigned to the group for human identification and communication.
element.requirements: Used to identify the group in human communication.

element.definition: A count of the number of resource instances that are part of the group.
element.requirements: Group size is a common defining characteristic.

element.short: Entity that is the custodian of the Group's definition
element.definition: Entity responsible for defining and maintaining Group characteristics and/or registered members.

element.short: Include / Exclude group members by Trait
element.definition: Identifies traits whose presence r absence is shared by members of the group.
element.requirements: Needs to be a generic mechanism for identifying what individuals can be part of a group.

element.requirements: Allows identification of the family member history as it is known by various participating systems and in a way that remains consistent across servers.

element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this FamilyMemberHistory.
The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this FamilyMemberHistory.
A code specifying the status of the record of the family history of a specific family member.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labelled as a modifier because it is a status element that contains status entered-in-error which means that the resource should not be treated as valid

binding.description: A code that identifies the status of the family history record.

element.definition: Describes why the family member's history is not available.
element.requirements: This is a separate element to allow it to have a distinct binding from reasonCode.

binding.description: Codes describing the reason why a family member's history is not available.

element.definition: The person who this history concerns.

element.short: When history was recorded or last updated
element.definition: The date (and possibly time) when the family member history was recorded or last updated.
element.requirements: Allows determination of how current the summary is.

element.definition: This will either be a name or a description; e.g. "Aunt Susan", "my cousin with the red hair".
element.requirements: Allows greater ease in ensuring the same person is being talked about.

element.definition: The type of relationship this person has to the patient (father, mother, brother etc.).

binding.description: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the related person being described in the family member history.

element.definition: The birth sex of the family member.
element.requirements: Not all relationship codes imply sex and the relative's sex can be relevant for risk assessments.

binding.description: Codes describing the sex assigned at birth as documented on the birth registration.

element.definition: The actual or approximate date of birth of the relative.
element.requirements: Allows calculation of the relative's age.

element.definition: The age of the relative at the time the family member history is recorded.
element.requirements: While age can be calculated from date of birth, sometimes recording age directly is more natural for clinicians.

element.definition: If true, indicates that the age value specified is an estimated value.
element.requirements: Clinicians often prefer to specify an estimaged age rather than an age range.
element.meaningWhenMissing: It is unknown whether the age is an estimate or not

element.definition: Deceased flag or the actual or approximate age of the relative at the time of death for the family member history record.

element.short: Why was family member history performed?
element.definition: Describes why the family member history occurred in coded or textual form, or Indicates a Condition, Observation, AllergyIntolerance, or QuestionnaireResponse that justifies this family member history event.

binding.description: Codes indicating why the family member history was done.

element.short: Condition that the related person had

element.definition: Indicates what happened following the condition.  If the condition resulted in death, deceased date is captured on the relation.

element.short: Whether the condition contributed to the cause of death

Either the age of onset, range of approximate age or descriptive string can be recorded.  For conditions with multiple occurrences, this describes the first known occurrence.
element.requirements: Age of onset of a condition in relatives is predictive of risk for the patient.

element.definition: An area where general notes can be placed about this specific condition.

element.definition: Indicates what happened following the procedure. If the procedure resulted in death, deceased date is captured on the relation.

element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this activity definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this activity definition is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the activity definition is stored on different servers.
element.requirements: Allows the activity definition to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.short: Additional identifier for the activity definition
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this activity definition when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the activity definition
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the activity definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the activity definition author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence. To provide a version consistent with the Decision Support Service specification, use the format Major.Minor.Revision (e.g. 1.0.0). For more information on versioning knowledge assets, refer to the Decision Support Service specification. Note that a version is required for non-experimental active assets.

element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the activity definition.

element.definition: An explanatory or alternate title for the activity definition giving additional information about its content.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this activity definition is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level activity definition.

element.short: Type of individual the activity definition is intended for
element.definition: A code, group definition, or canonical reference that describes  or identifies the intended subject of the activity being defined.  Canonical references are allowed to support the definition of protocols for drug and substance quality specifications, and is allowed to reference a MedicinalProductDefinition, SubstanceDefinition, AdministrableProductDefinition, ManufacturedItemDefinition, or PackagedProductDefinition resource.
element.meaningWhenMissing: Patient

binding.description: The possible types of subjects for an activity (E.g. Patient, Practitioner, Organization, Location, etc.).

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the activity definition was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the activity definition changes.

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the activity definition.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the activity definition.  May also allow for contact.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.short: Natural language description of the activity definition
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the activity definition from a consumer's perspective.

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate activity definition instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for activity definition (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the activity definition is intended to be used.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.short: Why this activity definition is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this activity definition is needed and why it has been designed as it has.

element.short: Describes the clinical usage of the activity definition
element.definition: A detailed description of how the activity definition is used from a clinical perspective.
A copyright statement relating to the activity definition and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the activity definition.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the activity definition and/or its content.

element.short: When the activity definition was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.

element.short: When the activity definition was last reviewed
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

element.short: When the activity definition is expected to be used
element.definition: The period during which the activity definition content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the activity definition are or are expected to be used instead.

element.definition: Descriptive topics related to the content of the activity. Topics provide a high-level categorization of the activity that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the activity definition so that it can be found by topical searches.

binding.description: High-level categorization of the definition, used for searching, sorting, and filtering.

element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.
An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.
An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.
An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.
Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, or bibliographic references.
element.requirements: Activity definitions must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

element.short: Logic used by the activity definition
element.definition: A reference to a Library resource containing any formal logic used by the activity definition.

A description of the kind of resource the activity definition is representing. For example, a MedicationRequest, a ServiceRequest, or a CommunicationRequest. Typically, but not always, this is a Request resource.

binding.description: The kind of activity the definition is describing.

element.short: What profile the resource needs to conform to
element.definition: A profile to which the target of the activity definition is expected to conform.
element.requirements: Allows profiles to be used to describe the types of activities that can be performed within a workflow, protocol, or order set.

element.definition: Detailed description of the type of activity; e.g. What lab test, what procedure, what kind of encounter.
element.requirements: Allows matching performed to planned as well as validation against protocols.

binding.description: Detailed type of the activity; e.g. CBC.

element.short: proposal | plan | directive | order | original-order | reflex-order | filler-order | instance-order | option
element.definition: Indicates the level of authority/intentionality associated with the activity and where the request should fit into the workflow chain.

binding.description: Codes indicating the degree of authority/intentionality associated with a request.

element.definition: Indicates how quickly the activity  should be addressed with respect to other requests.

binding.description: Identifies the level of importance to be assigned to actioning the request.

element.short: True if the activity should not be performed
element.definition: Set this to true if the definition is to indicate that a particular activity should NOT be performed. If true, this element should be interpreted to reinforce a negative coding. For example NPO as a code with a doNotPerform of true would still indicate to NOT perform the action.
element.isModifierReason: If true this element negates the specified action. For Example,  instead of a request for a procedure, it is a request for the procedure to not occur.

element.definition: The timing or frequency upon which the described activity is to occur.
element.requirements: Allows prompting for activities and detection of missed planned activities.

element.definition: Identifies the facility where the activity will occur; e.g. home, hospital, specific clinic, etc.
element.requirements: Helps in planning of activity.

element.short: Who should participate in the action
element.definition: Indicates who should participate in performing the action described.

element.definition: The type of participant in the action.

element.definition: The type of participant in the action.
The role the participant should play in performing the described action.

binding.description: Defines roles played by participants for the action.

element.definition: Indicates how the actor will be involved in the action - author, reviewer, witness, etc.
Identifies the food, drug or other product being consumed or supplied in the activity.

binding.description: Code describing the type of substance or medication.

element.definition: Identifies the quantity expected to be consumed at once (per dose, per meal, etc.).
Provides detailed dosage instructions in the same way that they are described for MedicationRequest resources.

element.short: What part of body to perform on
element.definition: Indicates the sites on the subject's body where the procedure should be performed (I.e. the target sites).
element.requirements: Knowing where the procedure is made is important for tracking if multiple sites are possible.

binding.description: A code that identifies the anatomical location.

element.short: What specimens are required to perform this action
element.definition: Defines specimen requirements for the action to be performed, such as required specimens for a lab test.
element.requirements: Needed to represent lab order definitions.

element.short: What observations are required to perform this action
element.definition: Defines observation requirements for the action to be performed, such as body weight or surface area.
element.requirements: Needed to represent observation definitions.

element.short: What observations must be produced by this action
element.definition: Defines the observations that are expected to be produced by the action.
A reference to a StructureMap resource that defines a transform that can be executed to produce the intent resource using the ActivityDefinition instance as the input.

element.short: The path to the element to be set dynamically
element.definition: The path to the element to be customized. This is the path on the resource that will hold the result of the calculation defined by the expression. The specified path SHALL be a FHIRPath resolveable on the specified target type of the ActivityDefinition, and SHALL consist only of identifiers, constant indexers, and a restricted subset of functions. The path is allowed to contain qualifiers (.) to traverse sub-elements, as well as indexers ([x]) to traverse multiple-cardinality sub-elements (see the [Simple FHIRPath Profile](http://build.fhir.org/fhirpath.html#simple) for full details).

element.definition: An expression specifying the value of the customized element.

element.definition: A group of related requests that can be used to capture intended activities that have inter-dependencies such as "give this medication after that one".

element.requirements: Allows identification of the request as it is known by various participating systems and in a way that remains consistent across servers.

A plan, proposal or order that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this request.
element.requirements: Allows tracing of authorization for the request and tracking whether proposals/recommendations were acted upon.

element.definition: Completed or terminated request(s) whose function is taken by this new request.
element.requirements: Allows tracing the continuation of a therapy or administrative process instantiated through multiple requests.

element.short: Composite request this is part of
element.definition: A shared identifier common to all requests that were authorized more or less simultaneously by a single author, representing the identifier of the requisition, prescription or similar form.
element.requirements: Some business processes need to know if multiple items were ordered as part of the same "prescription" or "requisition" for billing or other purposes.

element.short: draft | active | on-hold | revoked | completed | entered-in-error | unknown
element.definition: The current state of the request. For request groups, the status reflects the status of all the requests in the group.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because it is a status element that contains status entered-in-error which means that the resource should not be treated as valid

element.definition: Indicates the level of authority/intentionality associated with the request and where the request fits into the workflow chain.
element.requirements: Proposals/recommendations, plans and orders all use the same structure and can exist in the same fulfillment chain.
element.isModifierReason: This element changes the interpretation of all descriptive attributes. For example "the time the request is recommended to occur" vs. "the time the request is authorized to occur" or "who is recommended to perform the request" vs. "who is authorized to perform the request

resource.name: Provenance Relevant History
resource.description: Guidance on using Provenance for related history elements

element.short: Who, What, When for a set of resources
element.definition: Provenance of a resource is a record that describes entities and processes involved in producing and delivering or otherwise influencing that resource. Provenance provides a critical foundation for assessing authenticity, enabling trust, and allowing reproducibility. Provenance assertions are a form of contextual metadata and can themselves become important records with their own provenance. Provenance statement indicates clinical significance in terms of confidence in authenticity, reliability, and trustworthiness, integrity, and stage in lifecycle (e.g. Document Completion - has the artifact been legally authenticated), all of which may impact security, privacy, and trust policies.

element.short: Canonical identifier for this value set, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this value set is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the value set is stored on different servers.
element.requirements: Allows the value set to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.short: Additional identifier for the value set (business identifier)
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this value set when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the value set
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the value set author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.

element.short: Name for this value set (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the value set. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this value set (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the value set.

The status of this value set. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content. The status of the value set applies to the value set definition (ValueSet.compose) and the associated ValueSet metadata. Expansions do not have a state.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this value set is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level value set.

element.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the value set was created or revised (e.g. the 'content logical definition').

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the value set.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the value set.  May also allow for contact.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.short: Natural language description of the value set
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the value set from a consumer's perspective. The textual description specifies the span of meanings for concepts to be included within the Value Set Expansion, and also may specify the intended use and limitations of the Value Set.

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate value set instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

resource.name: VSDALignedValueSet
resource.title: Value Set Definition Aligned Profile
resource.description: This profile defines the necessary extensions and constraints on ValueSet to align with the HL7 Specification: Characteristics of a Value Set Definition, Release 1 (VSD). This normative specification describes elements to create a ValueSet definition, and does not describe elements related to a ValueSet expansion.
resource.purpose: This profile defines the necessary extensions and constraints on ValueSet to align with the HL7 Specification: Characteristics of a Value Set Definition, Release 1 (VSD). This normative specification describes elements to create a ValueSet definition, and does not describe elements related to a ValueSet expansion.

element.short: A set of codes drawn from one or more code systems
element.definition: A ValueSet resource instance specifies a set of codes drawn from one or more code systems, intended for use in a particular context. Value sets link between [CodeSystem](http://build.fhir.org/codesystem.html) definitions and their use in [coded elements](http://build.fhir.org/terminologies.html).
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.

binding.description: IETF language tag

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
An Extension
Alternate human readable name that may declare a language and preferred indicator.

element.short: Canonical identifier for this value set, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this value set is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the value set is stored on different servers.
element.requirements: Allows the value set to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.short: Additional identifier for the value set (business identifier)
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this value set when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the value set
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the value set author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.requirements: Must be persisted with a ValueSet expansion.

element.short: Name for this value set (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the value set. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this value set (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the value set.

The status of this value set. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content. The status of the value set applies to the value set definition (ValueSet.compose) and the associated ValueSet metadata. Expansions do not have a state.
element.requirements: Must be persisted with a ValueSet expansion.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

Primitive value for code

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this value set is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level value set.

element.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the value set was created or revised (e.g. the 'content logical definition').

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the value set.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the value set.  May also allow for contact.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.short: Natural language description of the value set
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the value set from a consumer's perspective. The textual description specifies the span of meanings for concepts to be included within the Value Set Expansion, and also may specify the intended use and limitations of the Value Set.

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate value set instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for value set (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the value set is intended to be used.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.short: Indicates whether or not any change to the content logical definition may occur
element.definition: If this is set to 'true', then no new versions of the content logical definition can be created.  Note: Other metadata might still change.

element.short: Why this value set is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this value set is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
A copyright statement relating to the value set and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the value set.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the value set and/or its content.

element.short: A property/filter defined by the code system
element.definition: A code that identifies a property or a filter defined in the code system.

element.short: = | is-a | descendent-of | is-not-a | regex | in | not-in | generalizes | child-of | descendent-leaf | exists
element.definition: The kind of operation to perform as a part of the filter criteria.

binding.description: The kind of operation to perform as a part of a property based filter.

element.short: Code from the system, or regex criteria, or boolean value for exists
element.definition: The match value may be either a code defined by the system, or a string value, which is a regex match on the literal string of the property value  (if the filter represents a property defined in CodeSystem) or of the system filter value (if the filter represents a filter defined in CodeSystem) when the operation is 'regex', or one of the values (true and false), when the operation is 'exists'.

element.short: Select the contents included in this value set
element.definition: Selects the concepts found in this value set (based on its value set definition). This is an absolute URI that is a reference to ValueSet.url.  If multiple value sets are specified this includes the intersection of the contents of all of the referenced value sets.

element.short: A copyright statement for the specific code system included in the value set
element.definition: Exclusive right given to an originator or an assignee to print, publish, perform, film or record material and to authorize others to do the same.

element.short: Explicitly exclude codes from a code system or other value sets
element.definition: Exclude one or more codes from the value set based on code system filters and/or other value sets.

element.short: Property to return if client doesn't override
element.definition: A property to return in the expansion, if the client doesn't ask for any particular properties. May be either a code from the code system definition (convenient) or a the formal URI that refers to the property. The special value '*' means all properties known to the server.

element.short: Used when the value set is "expanded"
element.definition: A value set can also be "expanded", where the value set is turned into a simple collection of enumerated codes. This element holds the expansion, if it has been performed.

element.definition: An identifier that uniquely identifies this expansion of the valueset, based on a unique combination of the provided parameters, the system default parameters, and the underlying system code system versions etc. Systems may re-use the same identifier as long as those factors remain the same, and the expansion is the same, but are not required to do so. This is a business identifier.
The time at which the expansion was produced by the expanding system.

element.short: Total number of codes in the expansion
element.definition: The total number of concepts in the expansion. If the number of concept nodes in this resource is less than the stated number, then the server can return more using the offset parameter.

element.short: Offset at which this resource starts
element.definition: If paging is being used, the offset at which this resource starts.  I.e. this resource is a partial view into the expansion. If paging is not being used, this element SHALL NOT be present.
element.meaningWhenMissing: Paging is not being used

element.short: If user cannot select this entry
element.definition: If true, this entry is included in the expansion for navigational purposes, and the user cannot select the code directly as a proper value.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If this is not populated, systems can assume that the concept it not abstract. This SHALL always be populated for abstract concepts

element.short: If concept is inactive in the code system
element.definition: If the concept is inactive in the code system that defines it. Inactive codes are those that are no longer to be used, but are maintained by the code system for understanding legacy data. It might not be known or specified whether an concept is inactive (and it may depend on the context of use).

element.short: Version in which this code/display is defined
element.definition: The version of the code system from this code was taken. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured, and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.

element.short: Code - if blank, this is not a selectable code
element.definition: The code for this item in the expansion hierarchy. If this code is missing the entry in the hierarchy is a place holder (abstract) and does not represent a valid code in the value set.
The recommended display for this item in the expansion.

Additional representations for this item - other languages, aliases, specialized purposes, used for particular purposes, etc. These are relevant when the conditions of the expansion do not fix to a single correct representation.

element.definition: The general focus of the Value Set as it relates to the intended semantic space. This can be the information about clinical relevancy or the statement about the general focus of the Value Set, such as a description of types of messages, payment options, geographic locations, etc.

element.short: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be included and why
element.definition: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be included and why.

element.short: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be excluded and why
element.definition: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be excluded and why.

resource.name: Shareable CodeSystem
resource.description: Enforces the minimum information set for the value set metadata required by HL7 and other organizations that share and publish value sets

element.short: Declares the existence of and describes a code system or code system supplement
element.definition: The CodeSystem resource is used to declare the existence of and describe a code system or code system supplement and its key properties, and optionally define a part or all of its content.
The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.

binding.description: IETF language tag

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.

element.short: Canonical identifier for this code system, represented as a URI (globally unique) (Coding.system)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this code system when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this code system is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the code system is stored on different servers. This is used in [Coding](http://build.fhir.org/datatypes.html#Coding).system.
element.requirements: Allows the code system to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.short: Additional identifier for the code system (business identifier)
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this code system when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the code system (Coding.version)
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the code system when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the code system author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence. This is used in [Coding](http://build.fhir.org/datatypes.html#Coding).version.

element.short: Name for this code system (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the code system. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this code system (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the code system.
The date (and optionally time) when the code system resource was created or revised.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this code system is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level code system.

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the code system was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the code system changes.

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the code system.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the code system.  May also allow for contact.

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.short: Natural language description of the code system
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the code system from a consumer's perspective.

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate code system instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for code system (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the code system is intended to be used.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.short: Why this code system is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this code system is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
A copyright statement relating to the code system and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the code system.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the code system and/or its content.

element.short: If code comparison is case sensitive
element.definition: If code comparison is case sensitive when codes within this system are compared to each other.

element.short: Canonical reference to the value set with entire code system
element.definition: Canonical reference to the value set that contains the entire code system.
The meaning of the hierarchy of concepts as represented in this resource.

binding.description: The meaning of the hierarchy of concepts in a code system.

element.short: If code system defines a compositional grammar
element.definition: The code system defines a compositional (post-coordination) grammar.
This flag is used to signify that the code system does not commit to concept permanence across versions. If true, a version must be specified when referencing this code system.
The extent of the content of the code system (the concepts and codes it defines) are represented in this resource instance.

binding.description: The extent of the content of the code system (the concepts and codes it defines) are represented in a code system resource.

element.short: Canonical URL of Code System this adds designations and properties to
element.definition: The canonical URL of the code system that this code system supplement is adding designations and properties to.

element.short: Total concepts in the code system
element.definition: The total number of concepts defined by the code system. Where the code system has a compositional grammar, the basis of this count is defined by the system steward.

element.short: Filter that can be used in a value set
element.definition: A filter that can be used in a value set compose statement when selecting concepts using a filter.

Allows a service to provide  unique, business identifiers for the response.
An identifier, CodeableConcept or canonical reference to the guidance that was requested.
An identifier, CodeableConcept or canonical reference to the guidance that was requested.

element.short: success | data-requested | data-required | in-progress | failure | entered-in-error
element.definition: The status of the response. If the evaluation is completed successfully, the status will indicate success. However, in order to complete the evaluation, the engine may require more information. In this case, the status will be data-required, and the response will contain a description of the additional required information. If the evaluation completed successfully, but the engine determines that a potentially more accurate response could be provided if more data was available, the status will be data-requested, and the response will contain a description of the additional requested information.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labelled as a modifier because it is a status element that contains status entered-in-error which means that the resource should not be treated as valid

binding.description: The status of a guidance response.

element.short: Patient the request was performed for
element.definition: The patient for which the request was processed.

element.short: Encounter during which the response was returned
element.definition: The encounter during which this response was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.

element.short: When the guidance response was processed
element.definition: Indicates when the guidance response was processed.
Provides a reference to the device that performed the guidance.

Describes the reason for the guidance response in coded or textual form, or Indicates the reason the request was initiated. This is typically provided as a parameter to the evaluation and echoed by the service, although for some use cases, such as subscription- or event-based scenarios, it may provide an indication of the cause for the response.
Provides a mechanism to communicate additional information about the response.

element.short: Messages resulting from the evaluation of the artifact or artifacts
element.definition: Messages resulting from the evaluation of the artifact or artifacts. As part of evaluating the request, the engine may produce informational or warning messages. These messages will be provided by this element.

element.short: The output parameters of the evaluation, if any
element.definition: The output parameters of the evaluation, if any. Many modules will result in the return of specific resources such as procedure or communication requests that are returned as part of the operation result. However, modules may define specific outputs that would be returned as the result of the evaluation, and these would be returned in this element.
The actions, if any, produced by the evaluation of the artifact.

If the evaluation could not be completed due to lack of information, or additional information would potentially result in a more accurate response, this element will a description of the data required in order to proceed with the evaluation. A subsequent request to the service should include this data.

element.requirements: Allows tracing of authorization for the event and tracking whether proposals/recommendations were acted upon.

element.definition: A larger event of which this particular Observation is a component or step.  For example,  an observation as part of a procedure.

binding.description: Codes providing the status of an observation.

element.definition: A code that classifies the general type of observation being made.
element.requirements: Used for filtering what observations are retrieved and displayed.

binding.description: Codes for high level observation categories.

element.definition: Describes what was observed. Sometimes this is called the observation "name".
element.requirements: Knowing what kind of observation is being made is essential to understanding the observation.

binding.description: Codes identifying names of simple observations.

element.short: Who and/or what the observation is about
element.definition: The patient, or group of patients, location, device, organization, procedure or practitioner this observation is about and into whose or what record the observation is placed. If the actual focus of the observation is different from the subject (or a sample of, part, or region of the subject), the `focus` element or the `code` itself specifies the actual focus of the observation.
element.requirements: Observations have no value if you don't know who or what they're about.

element.short: What the observation is about, when it is not about the subject of record
element.definition: The actual focus of an observation when it is not the patient of record representing something or someone associated with the patient such as a spouse, parent, fetus, or donor. For example, fetus observations in a mother's record.  The focus of an observation could also be an existing condition,  an intervention, the subject's diet,  another observation of the subject,  or a body structure such as tumor or implanted device.   An example use case would be using the Observation resource to capture whether the mother is trained to change her child's tracheostomy tube. In this example, the child is the patient of record and the mother is the focus.

element.short: Healthcare event during which this observation is made
element.definition: The healthcare event  (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this observation is made.
element.requirements: For some observations it may be important to know the link between an observation and a particular encounter.

element.definition: The time or time-period the observed value is asserted as being true. For biological subjects - e.g. human patients - this is usually called the "physiologically relevant time". This is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection, but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
element.requirements: Knowing when an observation was deemed true is important to its relevance as well as determining trends.

element.definition: The time or time-period the observed value is asserted as being true. For biological subjects - e.g. human patients - this is usually called the "physiologically relevant time". This is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection, but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
element.requirements: Knowing when an observation was deemed true is important to its relevance as well as determining trends.

element.short: Date/Time this version was made available
element.definition: The date and time this version of the observation was made available to providers, typically after the results have been reviewed and verified.

element.short: Who is responsible for the observation
element.definition: Who was responsible for asserting the observed value as "true".
element.requirements: May give a degree of confidence in the observation and also indicates where follow-up questions should be directed.

element.definition: The information determined as a result of making the observation, if the information has a simple value.
element.requirements: An observation exists to have a value, though it might not if it is in error, or if it represents a group of observations.

element.definition: Provides a reason why the expected value in the element Observation.value[x] is missing.
element.requirements: For many results it is necessary to handle exceptional values in measurements.

binding.description: Codes specifying why the result (`Observation.value[x]`) is missing.

element.definition: A categorical assessment of an observation value.  For example, high, low, normal.
element.requirements: For some results, particularly numeric results, an interpretation is necessary to fully understand the significance of a result.

binding.description: Codes identifying interpretations of observations.

element.definition: Comments about the observation or the results.
element.requirements: Need to be able to provide free text additional information.

element.definition: Indicates the site on the subject's body where the observation was made (i.e. the target site).

binding.description: SNOMED CT Body site concepts

element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to perform the observation.
element.requirements: In some cases, method can impact results and is thus used for determining whether results can be compared or determining significance of results.

binding.description: Methods for simple observations.

element.definition: The specimen that was used when this observation was made.
The device used to generate the observation data.

Guidance on how to interpret the value by comparison to a normal or recommended range.  Multiple reference ranges are interpreted as an "OR".   In other words, to represent two distinct target populations, two `referenceRange` elements would be used.
element.requirements: Knowing what values are considered "normal" can help evaluate the significance of a particular result. Need to be able to provide multiple reference ranges for different contexts.
